[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., long, multi-clause sentences).
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing ("bespattered the white walls," "assumed the direction").
[PUNCTUATION]: Occasional comma splices in descriptive passages.

[LOGIC]: Abrupt transitions between events (e.g., moving from the 1830 revolution to the cholera outbreak without contextual linkage).
[CLARITY]: Sudden shifts in focus (e.g., the Silvela family’s role in Paris is introduced but not fully contextualized).
[STRUCTURE]: Minor inconsistencies in temporal sequencing (e.g., the timeline of family relocations is occasionally unclear).

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "flung out by passing strangers in regard to her work"
Awkward phrasing "should without exception be received"
[LEXICON]: Uncommon phrasing "installed herself at a farm"

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift from artistic development to domestic life details
Overly long list of judges in 1848 Salon with no paragraph break
[LOGIC]: Abrupt transition from sculpture studies to domestic menagerie
[TRANSITION]: Weak connection between 1848 Salon success and personal life changes
[CLARITY]: Unclear reference to "Mlle." at the end of the text

[GRAMMAR]: Sentence fragment: "Prosperity." (should be a complete sentence)
[SYNTAX]: Run-on sentences in the description of the oxen and the sale of the painting

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt transitions between paragraphs (e.g., from painting description to sales history)
[STRUCTURE]: Complex financial details about the replicas create potential confusion

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "She had now become celebrated, and the patrons of art fought among themselves for her productions."
Cumbersome structure in "Also, in depicting him... under a useful and noble aspect; now at the head of his oxen..."
[PUNCTUATION]: Comma splice in "The city of Ghent, to which she had loaned the Horse Fair for its exposition, demonstrated its gratitude..."
[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift in "And all this was only one part of her menagerie" with unclear connection to prior paragraph.

[LOGIC]: Sudden jump from Chevilly menagerie to her "no chance to rest" without clear causal link.
Disjointed shift from art criticism to Gambard's personal friendship.
[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from Paris studio to Scottish journey without temporal marker.
[CLARITY]: Unclear connection between Falkirk fair acquisitions and subsequent return to Paris.
[TRANSITION]: Unclear link between 1860 studio relocation and final anecdote about the Empress.

[GRAMMAR]: "owed her a grudge" (awkward phrasing; "held a grudge" is standard).
[SYNTAX]: "She herself had too high a regard for line-work to fail to bring to her task..." (overly complex structure).
[LEXICON]: "I must at once add..." (formal phrasing slightly disrupts flow).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from 1867 exposition to 1849 art school without clear chronological marker.
[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift from wartime actions to listing artworks ("From the host of works...") lacks smooth connection.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "submitted in advance to all the abuses and exigencies of the conquerors."
[PUNCTUATION]: Misplaced comma in "a German prince came to By, to pay his respects."
[LEXICON]: Unnatural word choice in "We should add that the Prussians..." (awkward phrasing for historical context).
[SPELLING]: Minor spelling inconsistency in "panthers" (should be "panthers" or "panthers"? Contextual ambiguity).

[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift from political resistance to artistic work after the peace treaty without clear linkage.
[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed flow between Rosa Bonheur’s personal life (Mlle. Micas, decorations) and her artistic achievements.
[LOGIC]: Unclear connection between descriptions of individual artworks (e.g., *The Lion Meditating*) and broader narrative of her career.
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous reference to "this epoch" in "It was also about this time..." without clear temporal anchoring.

[LEXICON]: Use of archaic/old-fashioned phrasing ("flood-tide of youth," "concert of regrets," "cortège")
[SYNTAX]: Slightly wordy phrasing ("which had the appearance of having been painted," "without a dissenting note, without reserve")

[STRUCTURE]: Slight abruptness in transition from her death to the tribute section (though contextually logical)
[CLARITY]: Ambiguity in "this innumerable cortège that followed her bier" (could imply the cortège itself testified, rather than the crowd's presence)
